title: Is it okay for Christian musicians to make non-vulgar secular music or do they have to exclusively create Christian-themed material? - Quora

response.answer_text: Doctrinally speaking, there is nothing in the way of “thou shalts” about this, regardless of whether this question is asking about Christian musicians or Christian musicians, because there is a distinction between the two. In terms of music culture and fandom, I would say that there is a risk to the one’s musical career any time some sort of crossover is attempted. A Christian musician who records music with secular appeal and without an overt Gospel message runs the risk of being accused by his/her Christian fan base of compromising spiritual convictions for the sake of greater, worldly fame. A Christian musician otherwise known for secular music and who is “outed” as a Bible believer runs a similar risk of alienating fans who are hostile to Christianity as a matter of personal principle and find the disclosure off-putting . And for this latter group, I would encourage them to remember Jesus’s words in Matthew 5:15 concerning openness about one’s faith: Nor do people light a lamp and put it under a basket, but on a stand, and it gives light to all in the house. Personally I am fan of a little known niche of music that consists of Christian musicians who make pro-Gospel music that does in fact use a little vulgarity to point us back toward the cross. Consider 16 Horsepower’s song “Black Bush” I can sense it all around me There's somethin' in this room It ain't magic nor no witchcraft No bitch on no broom Look see his bones are gone He done left the grave The grip of death it could not hold him down no It's for him that I rave Or “Last Song About Satan” by Slim Cessna’s Auto Club. I was at the Lion's Lair and who did I sit next to there but SatanHe ordered me a beer, and He looked me in the eyeHe said he was my friend, I knew that was a lieHe's the man behind my sins I seem to fall because of HimG___damn I hate Him. So this is my last song about SatanSo I say Lucifer you piece of shit I should kick your ass right where you sitAll the hell you put me through, my Mother cries because of You Granted, this kind of music will be objectionable to many mainstream Christians, but on the other hand it reaches many people where they live, in much more honest and less milquetoast terms.
